commits.message: fuzzer: further limit vertex count in Pajek files during fuzzing
fix: do not allow empty parameter names in Pajek files

issue.title: Should empty attribute names be prevented?
issue.body:
At the moment it is possible to create attributes with empty names, i.e. `""` is not rejected as an attribute name. This is probably not a good idea. Do we want to allow it?

Arguments against:

 - May be difficult to access in some interfaces (does work in R though).
 - Not possible to store in some file format (GML writer does modify it by adding "igraph" to it due to the default prefixing of any attribute name not starting with a letter).
 - Possible to store in file formats, but the resulting file is technically invalid (GraphML).
 - It is an edge case that _might_ need special handling in some cases. We are likely to forget about it.
 - There is just not much use for allowing it (?)

The new Pajek reader now preserves custom parameter names, and accepts the empty string, `""`, as a valid name. I am going to prevent this.

issue.title: Complete the set of biadjacency() functions
issue.body:
**What is the feature or improvement you would like to see?**

We now have `igraph_biadjacency()` and `igraph_get_biadjacency()` for unweighted dense biadjacency matrices.

This is a feature request to add support for weighted and for sparse graphs, achieving parity with the adjacency matrix functions. This is best done with API-breaking changes, so targeting for 0.11.

 - `igraph_get_biadjacency()` should get a `weights` parameter. This would be the only API-breaking change.
 - Add `igraph_weighted_biadjacency()`.
 - Add `igraph_biadjacency_sparse()` and `igraph_get_biadjacency_sparse()`.

**Use cases for the feature**

 - Parity with adj. mat. functions
 - These are already implemented in R/igraph, in pure R. Move them to C for improved robustness and consistency.

**Related**

 - #2196

commits.message: docs: small doc fix for biadjacency()

issue.title: Investigate NaN handling in adjacency matrix functions
issue.body:
NaN handling should be cleaned up in adjacency matrix functions.

Proposal:

 - In both the weighted and unweighted matrix -> graph conversion functions, any value that is not `isfinite()` should trigger an error (i.e. both NaN and Inf).
 - Leave the weighted graph -> matrix conversion function as-is.

It is tempting to try to pass through these values to the weight vector in the weighted function, but this is probably not very useful, and it is difficult to implement. Currently, probably even `matrix_is_symmetric()`, used by the UNDIRECTED mode, doesn't work well with NaNs. Several of the matrix conversion modes rely on arithmetic and comparison, which does not play well with NaN. Implementing special NaN handling for all of these is a lot of work for little gain.

The same issue applied to `biadjacency` functions as well.

Ref: https://github.com/igraph/rigraph/issues/918

comment.body: Or we can even convert `igraph_i_safe_real_to_int()` to a macro. I checked using GodBolt that this function compiles to very few instructions, so it is probably fast once inlined.

 - Leave the weighted graph -> matrix conversion function as-is.

It is tempting to try to pass through these values to the weight vector in the weighted function, but this is probably not very useful, and it is difficult to implement. Currently, probably even `matrix_is_symmetric()`, used by the UNDIRECTED mode, doesn't work well with NaNs. Several of the matrix conversion modes rely on arithmetic and comparison, which does not play well with NaN. Implementing special NaN handling for all of these is a lot of work for little gain.

Ref: https://github.com/igraph/rigraph/issues/918

comment.body: I guess that with LTO `igraph_i_safe_real_to_int()` would be inlined as well, right? I think we can safely assume that for performance-critical applications one would compile with LTO anyway.

issue.title: Investigate NaN handling in adjacency matrix functions
issue.body:
NaN handling should be cleaned up in adjacency matrix functions.

Proposal:

 - In both the weighted and unweighted matrix -> graph conversion functions, any value that is not `isfinite()` should trigger an error (i.e. both NaN and Inf).
 - Leave the weighted graph -> matrix conversion function as-is.

It is tempting to try to pass through these values to the weight vector in the weighted function, but this is probably not very useful, and it is difficult to implement. Currently, probably even `matrix_is_symmetric()`, used by the UNDIRECTED mode, doesn't work well with NaNs. Several of the matrix conversion modes rely on arithmetic and comparison, which does not play well with NaN. Implementing special NaN handling for all of these is a lot of work for little gain.

The same issue applied to `biadjacency` functions as well.

comment.body: If we want to be rigorous about this, we could use `igraph_i_safe_real_to_int()` instead of `isfinite()`. Performance impact unclear. `isfinite()` is inlined so its performance impact is very small.

commits.message: chore: improved comments for real -> int conversion [skip ci]

issue.title: Investigate NaN handling in adjacency matrix functions
issue.body:
NaN handling should be cleaned up in adjacency matrix functions.

Proposal:

 - In both the weighted and unweighted matrix -> graph conversion functions, any value that is not `is_finite()` should trigger an error (i.e. both NaN and Inf).
 - Leave the weighted graph -> matrix conversion function as-is.

It is tempting to try to pass through these values to the weight vector in the weighted function, but this is probably not very useful, and it is difficult to implement. Currently, probably even `matrix_is_symmetric()`, used by the UNDIRECTED mode, doesn't work well with NaNs. Several of the matrix conversion modes rely on arithmetic and comparison, which does not play well with NaN. Implementing special NaN handling for all of these is a lot of work for little gain.

The same issue applied to `biadjacency` functions as well.

issue.title: Wishlist: Read multi-relational networks from Pajek files
issue.body:
**What is the feature or improvement you would like to see?**

Suppose reading multi-relational data from Pajek files. In multi-relational networks, there are several edge sets. An example is the WordNet dataset at https://github.com/gephi/gephi/wiki/Datasets

In Pajek files, each relation type has an integer index, and can also have a name. For example, in the  WordNet datafile we have:

```
*Arcslist :1 "hypernym pointers"
```

```
*Arcslist :8 "grouped verb pointers"
```

etc.

The relation type is either in the link block (`*edges`, `*arcs`, etc.) or on an edge or arc line as:

````
3: 10 11
```

This means that edge `10 -- 11` is of type `3`.

The relation type can be stored as an additional edge attribute, and the reader can return an extra `strvector` that contains the name for each relation index.

**Use cases for the feature**
There are such files in the wild.

**References**
—

issue.title: Pajek writer: Warn when the graph has non-exportable attributes
issue.body:
**What is the feature or improvement you would like to see?**

`igraph_write_igraph_pajek()` should issue a warning when the graph has attributes that can't / won't be exported.  Unlike some other packages (e.g. NetworkX), we only export attributes which Pajek actually understands.

**Use cases for the feature**

Reduce user confusion and risk of data loss.

**References**
—

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -517,3 +517,154 @@ igraph_error_t igraph_sort_vertex_ids_by_degree(const igraph_t *graph,
     }
     return IGRAPH_SUCCESS;
 }
+
+/**
+ * \function igraph_construct_jdm
+ * \brief Constructs a joint degree matrix.
+ *
+ * \experimental
+ *
+ * The joint degree matrix of a graph contains the number of edges, or the sum of the weights, between vertices of
+ * degree i and degree j for every (i, j). The function populates a joint degree matrix and works on directed
+ * and undirected graphs. Self loops are only counted once. If either \p dout or \p din are <= 0, the JDM
+ * will be resized automatically in the dimensions of the max degree of the vertices in the graph.
+ *
+ * \param graph A pointer to an initialized graph object.
+ * \param jdm A pointer to an initialized integer matrix that will be resized. The values will be written here.
+ * \param dout An integer for the dimension of the matrix. If \p dout and \p din are greater than 0, the matrix will be
+ *        resized do dimensions (\p dout, \p din).
+ * \param din An integer for the dimension of the matrix. If \p dout and \p din are greater than 0, the matrix will be
+ *        resized do dimensions (\p dout, \p din).
+ * \param weights An initialized integer vector containing the weights of the edges. NULL if the JDM should sum
+ *        the number of edges rather than sum up the weights.
+ * \return Error code.
+ *
+ * Time complexity: O(E),
+ * where E is the number of edges in input graph.
+ */
+
+igraph_error_t igraph_construct_jdm(const igraph_t* graph,
+                                    igraph_matrix_int_t* jdm,
+                                    igraph_integer_t dout,
+                                    igraph_integer_t din,
+                                    const igraph_vector_int_t* weights) {
comment.body:
I am just noticing one more issue that we need to fix.  We should operate with real-values weights, which implies that we should also use real-values matrices.

Please refactor to use `igraph_matrix_t` for the JDM and `igraph_vector_t` for `weights` instead of the current `igraph_matrix_int_t` and `igraph_vector_int_t`.

pull_request.title: Joint degree matrix
pull_request.body:
Added:
- src/tests/unit/jdm.c
- src/tests/unit/jdm.out
- igraph_construct_jdm function in src/properties/degrees.c

igraph_construct_jdm constructs a joint degree matrix of a graph that either contains the number of edges (if NULL is passed as the weights parameter) or the sum of the weights (if the weights vector is passed) between vertices of degree i and degree j for every (i, j). The function populates a joint degree matrix and works on directed and undirected graphs. Self-loops are counted once.
